0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-eu-schulz-idUSKBN13411C	EU's Schulz says working with Trump will be 'harder'	"
PARIS The election of Donald Trump as the United States' 45th president will make work ""harder"" for the European Union
column2: the European Parliament President Martin Schulz said on Wednesday.""It will be hard
column3: harder than with previous administrations but he is the freely elected president
column4: Schulz said on Europe 1 radio.""We must respect the future president of the United States (...) I hope we will find a slot to cooperate
column5: he said.

column1: Republican Donald Trump stunned the world on Tuesday by defeating heavily favored Hillary Clinton in the race for the White House
column2: ending eight years of Democratic rule.

column1: (Reporting by Matthias Blamont; Editing by Sudip Kar-Gupta)"
1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-profile-idUSKBN1340YV	Trump rewrote political playbook in successful White House bid	"
By Bill Trott
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump's successful campaign for the White House broke every tradition and upended the political establishment with the same bluster
column2: hyperbole and media mastery that made him one of the world's best-known businessmen.Trump told supporters at a rally early on Wednesday he had received a call from his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton  congratulating him on his victory.From his grand Trump Tower escalator entrance into the Republican presidential race on June 16
column4: Trump managed to be simultaneously charismatic and combative
column5: elitist and populist
column6: lewd and pious as he drilled into a lode of polarity and anti-Washington anger among American voters.It was his first run for public office and Trump
column8: reality television star and self-confessed owner of a big ego
column10: not a campaign. He drew large
column11: enthusiastic crowds to rallies where people cheered him for ""just saying what everybody's thinking."" Critics labeled him misogynistic
column17: a demagogue and a sexual predator
column18: all accusations he denied.It took Trump
column20: little more than 10 months to vanquish 16 other Republican candidates and win the party's nomination
column21: becoming the first major party nominee without government experience since General Dwight Eisenhower in the 1950s. He drew a record number of votes in primary contests but in so doing created a rift in the Republican Party.Then Trump squared off against Clinton
column23: in a race marked by controversies that included upheaval in his staff
column24: charges he had groped women and unheeded demands that he release his tax records. He said that as president he would investigate Clinton for her use of email while secretary of state. He vowed to send her to jail.His campaign took a scandalous turn in October with the release of a 2005 video in which Trump
column26: told a television entertainment reporter that he liked to kiss women without invitation and that
column27: because he was rich and famous
column28: he could grab them by the genitals with impunity.Trump dismissed the remarks as ""locker room talk"" and denied the subsequent accusations from more than 10 women who said he had groped them or made unwanted sexual advances.GLOOM OVER AMERICA

column1: Throughout his campaign - and especially in his Republican convention speech in July - Trump described a dark America that had been knocked to its knees by China
column2: Mexico
column3: Russia and Islamic State. The American dream was dead
column4: he said
column5: smothered by malevolent business interests and corrupt politicians
column6: and he said he alone could revive it.Trump said he would make America great again through the force of his personality
column7: negotiating skill and business acumen. He offered vague plans to win economic concessions from China
column8: to build a wall on the southern U.S. border to keep out undocumented immigrants and to make Mexico pay for it. He vowed to repeal Obamacare while being the ""greatest jobs president that God ever created"" and has proposed refusing entry to the United States of people from war-torn Middle Eastern nations
column9: a modified version of an earlier proposed ban on Muslims.Trump promoted himself as the ultimate success story. He dated beautiful women
column11: had his own television show and erected skyscrapers that bore his name in big gold letters. Everything in his life was the greatest
column16: even though critics assailed his experiences with bankruptcies
column17: the failures of his Atlantic City
column19: casinos and what they viewed as the misplaced pride he showed when presented with evidence he avoided paying taxes.Trump had flirted with presidential runs in the past and some initially saw his campaign as a vanity project meant to indulge his ego and burnish his brand. It was expected to be short-lived but as the election season progressed
column21: winning state nominating contests despite an unconventional campaign that relied on large-scale rallies and mostly ignored grass-roots work.His hired advisers came to realize there was only so much they could do to rein in Trump. His inner circle was dominated by his three oldest children - Donald Jr.

column1: TWEET ATTACKS
The rise of Trump
column2: once a registered Democrat
column3: threatened to blow up the Republican Party. Its establishment challenged his commitment to their tenets and organized against him. Prominent Republicans - including former presidents George H.W. Bush and George W. Bush and congressional leaders - shunned him or offered lukewarm support.Trump used Twitter as a weapon
column4: firing off insults and mockery at those who offended him
column5: including ""Crooked Hillary"" and Republican rivals ""Little Marco"" Rubio
column6: Jeb ""Low Energy"" Bush and ""Lyin' Ted"" Cruz.Another target was the family of a Muslim U.S. Army captain who died fighting in Iraq after the soldier's father had spoken against Trump at the Democratic National Convention. Trump sniped back for days despite his advisers urging him to move on.As of late October
column7: The New York Times had counted 282 people and things he had insulted on Twitter since declaring his candidacy.The Trump candidacy was brimming with contradictions. The candidate who vowed to bring back jobs to the United States had his clothing line and campaign hats manufactured in foreign countries. The man who decried the corrupting power of money in politics boasted of having bought influence himself.Undocumented workers had been used on his building projects but as a candidate Trump vowed to ship illegal immigrants out of the country. He said no one respected women more than he did but even before the groping accusations emerged
column8: he was branded a misogynist for making fun of the appearance of rival candidate Carly Fiorina and an apparent reference to the menstrual cycle of Fox News' Megyn Kelly.

column1: YOU'RE FIRED!""
Trump's campaign trail demeanor seemed to draw from his experiences as host of ""The Apprentice
column2: a reality TV show where he barked a crowd-pleasing ""You're fired!"" at contestants who fell short in competitions.His speeches were often unscripted and featured boasts on everything from his money to his IQ. He peppered them with dubiously sourced declarations
column3: misperceptions and false statements.He suggested that gun rights activists could act to stop Clinton from nominating liberal U.S. Supreme Court justices
column4: a remark the Clinton campaign called dangerous.Trump boasted of a fortune he put at $10 billion
column5: although in September Forbes magazine estimated it at $3.7 billion
column6: making him the 156th richest American.Trump regularly made comments that would have doomed a more conventional candidate
column7: such as when he said his supporters were so loyal that he could shoot someone on 5th Avenue in New York and not lose a single vote.In May he would draw accusations of racism for questioning the impartiality of a judge - born in the United States to Mexican immigrants - who was hearing a lawsuit against him.No other candidate referred to the size of his genitals during a debate. He was flattered when Russian President Vladimir Putin called him a ""brilliant and talented leader.""     Trump mocked Senator John McCain
column9: for having been captured during the Vietnam War and said he wanted to punch a protester in the face at a Trump rally.

column1: DIFFICULT CHILD
Trump was born to money on June 14
column3: in the New York City borough of Queens
column4: the fourth of five children of Fred Trump
column5: who would become one of the city's biggest developers and landlords
column6: and his wife. It was Fred Trump who taught Donald the value of self-promotion and a killer instinct.By his own admission
column7: Trump was not an easy child and in the eighth grade his parents sent him to the New York Military Academy in hopes of instilling needed discipline. Through student and medical deferments during the Vietnam War
column8: Trump would never serve in the U.S. military but said the school gave him ""more training militarily than a lot of the guys that go into the military.""After graduating from the University of Pennsylvania
column9: Trump went to work for his father's company
column10: which focused on the outer New York City boroughs of Queens
column11: Brooklyn and Staten Island and owned an estimated 15
column12: 000 apartments. In 1973 the Trumps were charged with racial bias in their rental practices before reaching a settlement with the U.S. government.With a $1 million loan from his father
column13: Trump eventually went into business himself in Manhattan
column14: where he became a regular at some of the city's most exclusive clubs and developed a reputation as a ladies' man.TRUMP TOWER FLAGSHIP

column1: He soon made his mark with a series of real estate and development deals
column2: including redoing an old hotel at New York's Grand Central Terminal. In 1983 he opened his flagship
column3: 58-story Trump Tower
column4: which serves as both his primary residence and Trump Organization headquarters.More projects around the world would follow
column5: including golf courses
column6: the Mar-a-Lago private resort in Florida
column7: New York's venerable Plaza Hotel and casinos.Trump's projects had mixed success. The flops included the real estate-oriented Trump University
column9: Trump Airlines and Trump Vodka but it was his experience with four casinos in Atlantic City
column11: that took the golden luster off his empire.Timothy O'Brien
column12: author of ""TrumpNation: The Art of Being the Donald
column13: wrote that in the 1990s Trump was out of money and twice had to go to his siblings for loans. A former employee said the Trump Organization would have shut down if the family had not come through but Trump disputed that in his 1997 book ""Trump: The Art of the Comeback.""While he never filed for personal bankruptcy
column14: the downturn in the gaming industry sent parts of Trump's corporate empire to bankruptcy court in 1991
column17: the unsecured creditors received less than a penny on the dollar for their claim. Trump resigned as chairman four days before the filing. (Writing and reporting by Bill Trott in Washington; Additional reporting by Diane Craft; Editing by Howard Goller)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-gambling-idUSKBN1332A6	Trump's chance of victory skyrockets on betting exchanges
column2: online market	"

column1: By Amy Tennery
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Online trading platform PredictIt and bookermaker Paddy Power showed a massive reversal of fortune for U.S. presidential candidates Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton on Tuesday night
column2: as the New York businessman's chances of taking the White House skyrocketed on both.Trump stunned many political experts
column3: showing a slight edge on Clinton in several swing states after voting had ended in more than two-thirds of the 50 U.S. states.Paddy Power put Trump's chance of victory at 83.3 percent Tuesday and Clinton's at 22.2 percent. The two had been in essentially opposite positions on Tuesday morning.The Irish bookmaker stands to take a $4 million hit if Trump wins
column4: said Paddy Power spokesman Feilim Mac An Iomaire
column5: who said the dramatic reversal in odds was reminiscent of what it saw in the ""Brexit"" vote for Britain to leave the European Union.""You could say it's deja vu again
column6: said Mac An Iomaire. ""Much like Brexit
column7: it looked to be following the odds early on before a dramatic turnaround.""

column1: While opinion polls went back and forth leading into Britain's June 23 referendum on whether or not to remain in the EU
column2: betting odds favored the ""remain"" campaign. Britons voted to leave by 52 percent to 48 percent. A similar trajectory played out on the online trading platform PredictIt
column3: which was launched in 2014 and is jointly run by Victoria University in Wellington
column4: New Zealand
column5: and Washington-based political consulting firm Aristotle International Inc.Clinton led Trump in PredictIt's market on who will win the White House throughout the campaign
column6: but news of her Republican challenger's surprise momentum sent her chance of winning the election plummeting roughly 75 percentage points from its level Tuesday morning to 5 percent.

column1: Trump's chance
column2: meanwhile
column3: shot up more than 40 percentage points to around 65 percent. It was the first time in the entire campaign that Trump had led Clinton on the platform
column4: according to a PredictIt spokeswoman.

column1: British gambling company Ladbrokes had Trump's chance of victory at roughly 85 percent Tuesday night
column2: compared with 15 percent for Clinton.Ladbrokes had earlier in the day placed Clinton's chance of victory at 76 percent and Trump's at 24 percent
column3: but company spokeswoman Jessica Bridge said the development ""isn't a surprise in the slightest
column4: given the high volume of trades made on Trump since the market opened in 2012.Roughly 75 percent of all bets in Ladbroke's U.S. presidential wagering had been placed on Trump. (Reporting By Amy Tennery; Editing by Grant McCool and Jonathan Oatis)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-mood-idUSKBN1332NC	U.S. voters want leader to end advantage of rich and powerful: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Americans who had cast their votes for the next president early on Tuesday appeared to be worried about the direction of the country
column2: and were looking for a ""strong leader who can take the country back from the rich and powerful
column3: according to an early reading from the Reuters/Ipsos national Election Day poll.The poll of more than 10
column4: 000 people who have already cast their ballots in the presidential election showed a majority of voters are worried about their ability to get ahead and have little confidence in political parties or the media to improve their situation. A majority also feel that the economy is rigged to mostly help the wealthy.The poll
column5: which will be updated as additional responses are tallied and votes are counted throughout Tuesday
column6: found:- 75 percent agree that ""America needs a strong leader to take the country back from the rich and powerful.""

column1: - 72 percent agree ""the American economy is rigged to advantage the rich and powerful.""- 68 percent agree that ""traditional parties and politicians don't care about people like me.""- 76 percent believe ""the mainstream media is more interested in making money than telling the truth.""
- 57 percent feel that ""more and more
column2: I don't identify with what America has become.""- 54 percent feel ""it is increasingly hard for someone like me to get ahead in America.""

column1: The Reuters/Ipsos online opinion poll was conducted on Election Day in English in all 50 states. It includes 10
column2: 604 Americans who have already cast their vote in the presidential election and has a credibility interval
column3: a measure of accuracy
column4: of 1 percentage point.  The poll also includes a variety of questions about the presidential race
column5: which candidate people supported
column6: and why. Those results will be published later in the evening
column7: after most of the votes have been counted and state races have been called. (Reporting by Chris Kahn; editing by Richard Valdmanis and Grant McCool)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-colorado-health-idUSKBN1340EM	Colorado voters reject measure to create universal healthcare	"
Colorado voters rejected a ballot measure on Tuesday to create the nation's first statewide universal health insurance program
column2: according to local NBC News affiliate 9News.The proposition
column3: called Amendment 69
column4: would have created one of the most dramatic overhauls to a public healthcare system in U.S. history.Colorado's 9News reported that the amendment was defeated on Tuesday night
column5: after early results showed an overwhelming defeat.Dubbed ColoradoCare
column6: the program would have been funded largely through a new 10 percent payroll tax increase intended to raise $25 billion in 2019
column7: the first year the program could launch
column8: according to the Colorado Health Institute.

column1: ColoradoCare was intended to greatly reduce the number of uninsured residents in the state
column2: but opponents feared the tax hike and sweeping changes to public policy would ripple through the state's economy.

column1: James Merilatt
column3: an unaffiliated voter who supported Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton in Tuesday's election
column4: said he opposed the single-payer healthcare measure.""It's way too complicated and would have opened up a Pandora's Box
column5: said Merilatt
column6: who works in the publishing industry.

column1: (Reporting by Robin Respaut; Additional reporting by Keith Coffman in Denver; Editing by Bill Trott and Jonathan Oatis)"
5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ryan-idUSKBN1340D5	Republican Speaker Ryan re-elected to U.S. House from Wisconsin	"
WASHINGTON Republican Paul Ryan was re-elected to the U.S. House of Representatives by voters in his Wisconsin district on Tuesday
column2: positioning him to reassert his claim to remain speaker of the House
column3: the highest-ranking post in the U.S. Congress.The 2012 vice presidential nominee
column4: if returned to the speaker's chair by House members
column5: may have a smaller Republican majority to work with if voters elect fewer Republicans. Most House races were still undecided.Like all members of the House
column6: other Republicans were also running for re-election from their home districts
column7: including House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of California and House Majority Whip Steve Scalise of Louisiana.Along with Ryan
column8: they were expected to seek re-election to their leadership posts. Closed-door leadership elections in both parties were expected to take place later in November. A new speaker will be elected by all members of Congress in January.

column1: Ryan
column3: has been speaker since October 2015. His re-election to that job is not certain. Some House conservatives have criticized him
column4: and they may have a stronger hand after Tuesday's voting.

column1: A number of Republican lawmakers were angered in October when Ryan said he would not campaign with or defend Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column2: who was in a closely fought race with Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton on Tuesday night.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Cornwell; Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Peter Cooney)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-problems-idUSKBN1332HN	U.S. election largely peaceful
column2: despite intimidation
column3: glitches	"

column1: By Julia Harte
column2: Andy Sullivan and David Ingram

column1: | WASHINGTON/PHILADELPHIA
WASHINGTON/PHILADELPHIA Voters and civil rights groups reported long lines
column2: isolated cases of malfunctioning equipment and some harassment at polling places in Tuesday's U.S. presidential election but fears of widespread violence at the polls did not materialize.Nationwide
column3: civil rights groups logged unusual levels of voter intimidation complaints
column4: receiving about 35
column5: 000 calls through a national voter complaint hotline as of Tuesday evening. Democratic Party officials
column7: said they did not see systemic voter suppression efforts.Civil rights groups
column10: said 40 percent of the calls they had received through the telephone hotline by early afternoon were from African-American and Latino voters.Complaints of voter intimidation were especially prevalent in Florida
column12: Ohio and Arizona with a disproportionate share coming from minority voters.""We are hearing more complaints about voter intimidation than we have in presidential cycles from prior years
column14: president of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights Under Law.Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump has repeatedly said the election would be ""rigged"" and called on his supporters to watch for signs of fraud in urban areas
column15: raising fears they could clash with minority voters. Numerous studies have found that voter fraud is exceedingly rare in the United States.VOTER INTIMIDATION

column1: Absent on Tuesday were reports of the kind of hostile political displays
column2: vandalism and violence that have cropped up regularly throughout the campaign. A polling station was locked down in Southern California after one person was killed and three wounded by gunfire but police saw no immediate indication the incident was linked to Election Day.But isolated reports of voter intimidation and harassment flooded the voter complaint hotline run by a coalition of civil rights groups throughout the day.An African-American voter called the hotline from Alabama's Shelby County to report that a white poll worker had indicated she would have to wash her hands after handling the voter's photo identification card.

column1: Shelby County lawyers persuaded the U.S. Supreme Court in 2013 to strike down a key provision of the landmark Voting Rights Act requiring states with a history of voter discrimination to get federal clearance for changes to their election laws.Clarke said many voter complaints to the hotline came from states formerly covered by that provision.Some voters in Florida reported a heavy
column2: unexplained police presence at several polling sites around the state. A group of students in the state were told their votes would not count because their college dormitory was considered a hotel. In Ohio's Franklin County
column3: the hotline received complaints that Somali-American voters were told they would have to vote provisionally because their addresses did not match their identification cards - and then were told that the polling site had run out of provisional ballots.In Georgia's DeKalb County
column4: a group calling itself Defenders of Democracy was pressuring voters in line to fill out sample ballots and sign pledges that they would cast the same votes on the real ballot
column5: according to reports received by the hotline.

column1: The federal government reduced its election monitoring program in the wake of a 2013 U.S. Supreme Court decision that weakened federal oversight of states with a history of racial discrimination. Revised voting laws and lengthy court battles in many states also have left voters uncertain about when and where they can cast their ballot and whether they will need to present photo identification. A Nevada judge on Tuesday rejected a request from Trump for records from a Las Vegas polling place that his campaign said had improperly remained open last week to accommodate people who were lined up to vote. The judge agreed with a county attorney who argued that election officials already preserve records. MACHINE GLITCHES
Malfunctioning machines dominated voter complaints out of Pennsylvania
column2: Arizona
column3: New York
column4: North Carolina and Virginia.Trump cited reports that polling machines were switching votes for Republican candidates to votes for Democrats as cause for concern that the election outcome might not be valid
column5: once again warning of a rigged system.

column1: Speaking to Fox News
column2: Trump provided no evidence to support the allegations or say where polling machines were breaking down
column3: although there were some problems in Pennsylvania.Voters in at least four Pennsylvania counties said touch-screen voting machines were mistakenly switching votes. State officials
column4: however
column5: said they did not believe any ballots had been wrongly counted as a result of the machine malfunctions.Pennsylvania is one of a handful of states that relies on electronic voting machines without a paper backup that would allow officials to double-check the outcome if it is challenged.The machines can record votes incorrectly if they are not calibrated properly
column6: a problem that is magnified as the screens degrade with age. But ES&S
column7: the company that makes the machines
column8: said voters have a chance to confirm their choices before they cast their ballot
column9: making it impossible for the machine to flip a vote from one candidate to another. Local officials test machines to make sure they are calibrated properly before each election.The Philadelphia district attorney's office
column10: which monitors voting in the state's largest city
column11: said on Twitter it was not receiving any complaints out of the ordinary.Electronic voting rolls in Durham County
column14: prompting the county to ask the state board of elections to extend voting hours in eight precincts until 9 p.m.
column15: an hour and a half later than they were supposed to be open.The state elections board on Tuesday evening agreed to extend voting hours in the precincts by between 20 and 60 minutes. (Additional reporting by Mark Hosenball; Editing by Andrew Hay and Bill Trott)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-north-carolina-idUSKBN1332Q8	Voting extended in North Carolina but not in Colorado after court requests	"
By Colleen Jenkins and Mica Rosenberg
| WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C./NEW YORK

column1: WINSTON-SALEM
column2: N.C./NEW YORK North Carolina extended voting times in several precincts during Tuesday's  presidential election but Colorado rejected a bid to keep polls open longer after both states experienced problems with electronic voting systems.In North Carolina
column3: advocates including the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had urged the state to extend voting time in eight Durham County precincts until 9 p.m. EST
column4: an hour and a half past normal closing time. Instead
column5: the state board extended voting time by an hour in two precincts and less than that in the other six.In Colorado
column6: the Democratic Party filed a petition in the Denver County District Court to extend voting for two additional hours after service failures in the state's electronic voting system in some polling places. A judge denied the request and said polls would close at 7 p.m. CST as scheduled.Colorado and North Carolina are both crucial battlegrounds in the U.S. presidential election between Republican Donald Trump and Democrat Hillary Clinton.

column1: The Colorado Secretary of State office had opposed the extension of voting hours.""This outage didn't stop anyone from voting. We have had two weeks of voting and everyone got a ballot
column2: Lynn Bartels
column3: a spokeswoman for the office
column4: said on Twitter. She said anyone still in line when polls closed would have an opportunity to cast their ballot.

column1: The Reverend William Barber
column2: president of the NAACP in North Carolina
column3: told members of the State Board of Elections on a conference call Tuesday evening that their refusal to extend voting hours as long as requested by local elections officials was ""deeply concerning.""The problem in North Carolina involved the electronic poll books used to check in voters in some precincts. At one precinct where voting was extended for 60 minutes
column4: election officials reported there had been up to a two-hour period earlier in the day where no voting took place.

column1: We've fought too much voter suppression in this state over and over again
column2: Barber said.Patrick Gannon
column3: spokesman for the North Carolina State Board of Elections
column4: said voting was extended in just a handful of the state's 2
column5: 704 precincts. The election board is made up of three Republicans and two Democrats. (Reporting by Colleen Jenkins in Winston-Salem
column6: North Carolina and Mica Rosenberg in New York; Additional reporting by Dan Levine in San Francisco; Editing by Lisa Shumaker and Bill Trott)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-outreach-idUSKBN13409J	Clinton campaign reached 25 percent of U.S. voters: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
WASHINGTON Americans voting in Tuesday's presidential election were far more likely to have been contacted by Democrat Hillary Clinton's campaign than Republican Donald Trump's
column2: according to an early reading from the Reuters/Ipsos Election Day poll.Some 25 percent of American voters said someone from the Clinton campaign either called them or talked to them in person about coming out to vote
column3: while 17 percent said the same about the Trump campaign
column4: according to the survey of about 38
column5: 000 people who had cast a ballot.Clinton far outspent Trump during the race for the White House
column6: setting up a sprawling campaign team that included hundreds of paid staff.

column1: Four years ago
column2: the get-out-the-vote operations were much more competitive. On Election Day 2012
column3: some 28 percent of voters said that they were contacted by the re-election campaign of President Barack Obama
column4: while 25 percent said they were contacted by his Republican challenger Mitt Romney's camp.

column1: Tuesday's poll reading will be updated as more poll responses are tallied and more votes are counted across the country.
(Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"
